newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast spot power steady amid thin demand.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast spot power steady amid thin demand.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. held steady Thursday versus Wednesday's levels amid thin incremental power demand due to cool, rainy weather, industry sources said.
"We're going to have fall weather through the weekend," said one Southeast trader said.
"We still feel the effect of cooler weather with these hurricanes back to back," he said, referring to Hurricane Fran last week and Hortense this week.

In the Southeastern Electric Reliability Council (SERC), peak, non-firm power for Friday was quoted at $19.00-$20.00 per megawatt hour (MWh), compared with Wednesday's range for thursday power in the $19.00-$21.00 area.
SERC non-firm, off-peak power for Friday was pegged at $12.50-$13.00, compared with $12.00-$13.00 on Wednesday.
At the Georgia/Florida border, peak, non-firm power prices for Friday were valued in the $23.00-$24.00, unchanged from Wednesday's level.
In the Florida peninsula, non-firm, peak electricity for Thursday was offerd at $23.00-$24.00 level, down from Wednesday's $24.00.
